title: Mondi wraps up 27pc profit rise as customers absorb price rises
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Oct 8, 2015, 09:40 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 50 mins Mondi wraps up 27pc profit rise as customers absorb price rises By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 3 minutes 50 seconds ago -19.0000 
Packaging group said demand was strong in almost all of its paper products 
Packaging maker Mondi (LSE: MNDI.L - news ) has said that price rises and steady revenues in most of its markets have helped to counteract the dent in sales from planned factory shutdowns and strained demand from some Middle Eastern and Asian regions. 
Mondi's operating profits in the three months to the end of September were up 27pc on the same time last year to €221m, helped by like-for-like sales increases in almost all of its packaging and paper products along with price rises. 
Maintenance shutdowns at its factories and a seasonal slowdown in some areas meant that third-quarter profits were 13pc lower than during the second quarter. The firm makes paper for consumer packaging, corrugated board and industrial uses. 
The FTSE 100 company said it expects to lose €90m of underlying profits as a result of shutdowns this year, in line with previous forecasts. Mondi, which is dual-listed in London and Johannesburg, is spending up to €1.1bn during this year and 2016 on upgrading its production facilities to match growing competition. 
Mondi also flagged that recycling costs in Europe had jumped 13pc in the past three months, although price rises have offset some of this extra expense and other costs such as wood and chemicals were broadly stable in local currencies. 
Sack kraft paper, which is used in food bags and cement packaging, was the exception in the group's growing sales. Mondi said export volumes were under pressure "due to a combination of political instability in the Middle East and North Africa and a slowdown in demand in certain south-east Asian markets". 
Foreign exchange fluctuations during the quarter had a mixed effect on the company, which said its South African operations benefited from the weakening rand while the Russian rouble’s drop meant fine paper sales in the country were relatively less valuable. 
“The group continues to deliver strongly, benefiting from stable to higher selling prices in a number of key grades and the contributions from its capital investment programme. Currency volatility has had a limited impact on the group, while costs remain generally stable,” Mondi said.
